Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is part of a larger initiative in the realm of 2 dimensional materials to envision and implement how data sciences can contribute to the development of this discipline to elucidate structure/processing/property correlations. At present, many materials problems of technological relevance suffer from lack of data frameworks. Indeed, lack of adequate frameworks to process, curate, and share complex raw data hinders progress in this field, ultimately not realizing the promise of 2 dimensional materials commercial technologies. In short, materials scientists are inundated with multi-dimensional data from many sources, both experimental and computational, and vast amounts of data are under-utilized, repeatedly acquired, or thrown out completely. purpose of this workshop is to provide students and postdocs with the adequate training to effectively build and use the needed framework towards sound data schemes and repositories in the realm of 2 dimensional materials.

This meeting is the first training event for students and postdocs of the recently constituted NSF-2D Data Framework (2DDF), which will be complemented by further training, as well as PI meetings that will result in a data platform, developed by PIs in a bottom up fashion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials underlie all aspects of modern life, providing the physical components driving everything from airplanes to medical robots. The advent of machine learning and “AI” techniques is poised to transform and accelerate progress in every scientific field, including materials science and materials discovery. In order to meet this promise, the materials research community must develop and disseminate the tools and techniques to enable data-driven discovery.

This project created the first data-centric workshop focused on the needs and interests of the 2D materials research community, specifically those within the DMR-2D research groups. The workshop was organized by the Platform for the Accelerated Realization, Analysis, and Discovery of Interface Materials (PARADIM), an NSF Materials Innovation Platform (MIP), in partnership with the NIST Office of Data and Informatics. The workshop was held from November 11-15, 2018 at the Mt. Washington Conference Center of Johns Hopkins University.

It brought together a diverse community that include graduate students, post-docs, faculty, and national laboratory scientist to learn/teach new concepts and skills for modern workforce development.  It also began the important process of community building required to develop a culture of data sharing and use.  Student feedback gathered through a survey at the end of the workshop shows significant gains in data-related thinking and highlighted four important findings that inform continued work to build materials data infrastructure that will help address the NSF Big Idea to Harness the Data Infrastructure. 

All teaching materials are publicly available at https://github.com/paradimdata/nsf_2d_workshop_2018/ for anyone in the world to use, extend, and share. Videos of the presentations are publically available at https://www.paradim.org/2D_data_workshops . In keeping with the principle that all reusable works should be citable, the materials used during the workshop are also permanently citable as a doi: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3722635 .

The curricular materials created form a foundation that has already been used in other settings including Summer School trainings for the PARADIM MIP (https://www.paradim.org/jhu_ss_2019), in which 20 attendees were exposed to data science as applied to materials, and reported significant gains in appreciation and perceived value of data rich techniques.  The curricular materials will be used again in 2020 as part of a Materials AI Workshop in planning at the Johns Hopkins University. Finally, the use of SciServer cyberinfrastructure has created a new application of these data rich tools that originate in astronomy.

 


Last Modified: 03/22/2020
Modified by: Tyrel Mcqueen
